StepDescription: Ensure ethernet cable is connceted to Internet
Plug the other port to IoT device
Check if wget http://www.kernel.org/pub/linux/bluetooth/bluez-5.30.tar.xz

Description: use gatttool to write IoT BLE handle value
StepDescription: IoT device does ble advertising. Command is: hciconfig hci0 leadv
On Host, gatttool -b <iot BT MAC> --characteristics

In the characteristics list, use a handle to see its value. Command is: 
gatttool -b <iot BT MAC> --char-read -a <handle>

Write new value into the handle by:
gatttool -b <iot BT MAC> --char-write-req -a <handle> -n abcd

Read this handle again. 
gatttool -b <iot BT MAC> --char-read -a <handle>
ExpectedResult: the value has been modified to 'ab cd ...'

StepDescription: Ubuntu15.04 ping IoT's ipv6 address
Ubuntu15.04 ssh to IoT via its ipv6 address
Ubuntu15.04 ping IoT's ipv6 address
Ubuntu15.04 ssh to IoT via its ipv6 address

Description: enable CAN bus to recognize can0
StepDescription: Run ifconfig after system boots up.

Description: send data to can0 and dump data
StepDescription: Send message to can0 bus. Command is: ./cansend can0 500#1E.10.10
In another terminal, receive message on can0: Command is: ./candump can0
Plug RS232 cable to the main-board
Check by minicom on PC to get the debugging output
ExpectedResult: info could be output on minicom

Description: Plug usb port to IoT and plug rs232 to PC
StepDescription: Plug usb port to IoT device
plug rs232 (with rs232-com cable) to the COM of PC
Run serial-test (source code is in attachment of the feature 381) on IoT device: serial-test /dev/ttyUSB0
On the other part, plug the serial port to a PC, launch COM1 with 115200. Enter YooHoo
